of microorganisms (bacteria, viruses, and
fungi) to antimicrobials and antiseptics represents one of the most
pressing challenges in modern medicine and biology.  Antimicrobial photodynamic
therapy (aPDT) has emerged as a promising
strategy for surface disinfection in healthcare settings, particularly
for medical equipment, high-touch surfaces, and implantable devices.  BODIPY fluorophores
have arisen as versatile PSs in aPDT, offering
a promising solution to combat drug-resistant pathogens.     Anionic
boron clusters (including cobaltabis­(dicarbollide) ([3,3′-Co­(1,2-C 2 9 11 2 − o 2 9 11 2 − o closo 12 12 2–   o-       o o  12 12 2–  12 12 2–  nido o  This study pioneers the integration of BODIPY cores with anionic
boron clusters for aPDT. While neutral and anionic boron cluster-BODIPY
conjugates have been explored for anticancer therapy and bioimaging,  BDP-COS BDP-FES BDP-B  12 closo 2 Results and Discussion 2.1 Synthesis and Structural

were performed under atmosphere of dinitrogen employing standard Schlenk
techniques. All reagents were purchased and used without further purification.
Acetonitrile was dried for 2 days over molecular sieves (3Å;
Merck; activated for 16h at 300 °C under vacuum). After drying,
acetonitrile was degassed using the well stablished freeze–pump–thaw
protocol. Reactions were monitored by TLC on precoated silica gel
plates (ALUGRAM SILG/UV254) and revealed by exposure to a UV254 lamp.
Flash column chromatography was performed using silica gel (230–400
mesh). Commercial grade tetrahydrofuran, methanol, ethanol, hexane,
dichloromethane and acetone were used without further purification.

of Photosensitizers Stocks solutions of the PSs were prepared
at 10 mM in 100% DMSO.
Intermediate solutions at 1 mM were prepared in distilled water, and
working solutions were further diluted in culture medium. 4.4.2 Microbial Strains and Growth Conditions The strains
used in this study were mostly retrieved from our own
collection. Staphylococcus aureus Enterococcus raffinosus Enterococcus faecium Escherichia coli Pseudomonas
aeruginosa Enterobacter aerogenes S. aureus E. coli P. aeruginosa E. aerogenes E. faecium E. raffinosus 4.4.3 Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing Minimum Inhibitory

method as previously described, www.eucast.org/clinicalbreakpoints/ 6 5 2 BDP-I  2 BDP-B  12 2 BDP-COS 4.4.4 Photodynamic Inactivation and Dose–Response
Assays Photodynamic inactivation assays were performed as
previously described, S. aureus E. faecium E. raffinosus E. coli P. aeruginosa E. aerogenes 8 S. aureus 4.4.5 Statistical Analyses Statistical
analyses were performed using GraphPad Prism v.9.0 software (San Diego,
CA, USA). Two-way ANOVA test was used to evaluate the differences
between groups. Supplementary Material This work was supported by grants PID2022-136892NB-I00,
